There were three design flaws in the system as it existed on September 10th.
One is that you had an official, the director of Central Intelligence, who was the president's senior intelligence advisor.
He was the overall coordinator of the 15, actually more, federal intelligence agencies.
And he was also the head of the CIA.
So he had three jobs.
Now, that was too much.
The other thing is, the technical intelligence agencies, you know, the spy satellites and so on, they're in the Defense Department.
And having them in the Defense Department has given the Defense Department a preponderant share of the intelligence budget.
And as a result, it kind of over-awes the other intelligence agencies.
So there's an argument for pulling them apart.
And finally, the third design flaw was giving the FBI the dominant role in domestic national security intelligence.

What we were missing, which every other country, virtually every other country in the world that I know of, has is a separate domestic intelligence agency which doesn't have a criminal investigation function.
It's just, you know, information gathering.
